title: The pomeron in closed bosonic string theory

title_detail.value: The pomeron in closed bosonic string theory

summary:
We review the features of the pomeron in the S-matrix theory and in quantum
field theory. We extend those general properties to the pomeron of closed
bosonic string theory in a Minkowskian background. We compute the couplings of
the pomeron to the lowest mass levels of closed bosonic string states in flat
space. We recognize the deviation from the linearity of the Regge trajectories
in a five dimensional anti De Sitter background.

summary_detail.value:
We review the features of the pomeron in the S-matrix theory and in quantum
field theory. We extend those general properties to the pomeron of closed
bosonic string theory in a Minkowskian background. We compute the couplings of
the pomeron to the lowest mass levels of closed bosonic string states in flat
space. We recognize the deviation from the linearity of the Regge trajectories
in a five dimensional anti De Sitter background.

author: A. R. Fazio
fulltext:
The pomeron in closed bosonic string theory

arXiv:1002.4028v1 [hep-th] 22 Feb 2010

A.R. Fazio
Departamento de Fisica, Universidad Nacional de Colombia
Ciudad Universitaria, Bogotá, D.C. Colombia
arfazio@unal.edu.co

November 12, 2018
Abstract
We review the features of the pomeron in the S-matrix theory and in quantum field
theory. We extend those general properties to the pomeron of closed bosonic string
theory in a Minkowskian background. We compute the couplings of the pomeron to
the lowest mass levels of closed bosonic string states in flat space. We recognize the
deviation from the linearity of the Regge trajectories in a five dimensional anti De
Sitter background.

1

Introduction

Consider the 2 → 2 scattering amplitude for the process
A + B → A′ + B ′ .
The Lorentz covariance of the S-matrix requires the scattering amplitude to be written in
terms of the Mandelstam variables
s = (pA + pB )2

t = (pA − pA′ )2 u = (pA − pB′ )2

(1)

which, for particles of equal masses, are related each others by
s + u + t = 4m2 .

(2)

The Lorentz invariant scattering amplitude can be written as function of just s and t, A(s, t),
to be studied in the Regge kinematical regime
s ≈ −u >> m2 ≈ −t ≈ |~q|2 ≈ E 2 θ2

(3)

being q the transferred momentum in the center of mass frame, pA − pA′ . E is the center of
mass energy of the approaching particles and θ is the scattering angle. To work in the Regge
limit Sudakov's paramenters s1 , s2 are useful. The transferred momentum gets decomposed
as
s1
s2
q = ~q − pB + pA
(4)
s
s
1

 with the orthogonality relation
~q * pA = 0 = ~q * pB .

(5)

Putting all masses to zero, as in the high energy regime, we have the decomposition
q = ~q +

~q 2 + m2
(pA − pB )
s

(6)

and, in the Regge limit, we can make the replacement q ≈ ~q. In the next ~q will be treated
as a two dimensional vector, since (5) implies the orthogonality to the scattering direction.
Due to the Sudakov's parametrization we may write
ds1 ds2 d2 q

imaginary part of the forward scattering amplitude. The total cross section is defined as

of the scattering amplitude
Z

(10)
being χ(s, ρ~) the eikonal phase and ρ~ the impact parameter, the two-dimensional vector dual
Fourier variable of the transfered momentum ~q. From the the optical theorem (9) we deduce
Z
σα = 2 d2 ρ R(1 − eiχ(s,~ρ) ),
(11)

of representing the scattering amplitude by its Mellin transform

with a > 0. The integral is performed on a contour made by the straight vertical line at
Rω = a and leaving on its right all singularities of the integrand in the ω complex plane. The
2

p = ±1, explicitly appearing in the signature factor as
ξp (ω) = −

and meaning the parity of the partial waves under the s ↔ u exchange. The sinus factor in

Making the Regge limit, A(s, t) looks as in (13) because Pl (cosθ) = Pl 1 + 2st goes to st ,
and fp (ω, t) are the analitical continuation of the partial waves with definite signature.
Assuming the partial wave fp (ω, t) to have isolated poles, the moving poles, with the usual
factorized residue:
γAp (t)γBp (t)
(16)

and replacing the previous into (13), we get in the Regge limit
Ap (s, t) ≈

ξp (ωp (t))γAp (t)γBp (t)sωp (t)
.
Γ(ωp (t))

(17)

The result (17) is understood as the exchange in the t-channel of a spin continous object,
the Reggeon, whose spin ωp (t) is called Regge trajectory. In linear approximation it depends
on just two parameters, the intercept ωp (0) and the Regge slope αp′
ωp (t) = ωp (0) + αp′ t.

(18)

For t > 0 we have particles exchanged in the t-channel when t = m2i and ωp (m2i ) = Ji ,
the physical spin. The Reggeon having the vacuum quantum numbers (spin zero, C=+1,
P=+1) and positive signature is the Pomeron. The contribution of such a trajectory to the
total cross section is proportional to
sω(0)−1 γ(0),

(19)

which agrees with the Pomeranchuk theorem of the increasing of the total cross section
with energy due to the exchange of the vacuum quantum numbers, if (ω(0) − 1) > 1. The
asymptotic behaviour of scattering amplitudes in the Born approximation is governed by
the spin σ of the exchanged particle in the t-channel. In quantum chromodynamics such
a leading behaviour is given by the so called reggezeid gluon. We just spend few words
about the meaning of reggezeid particle [1]. When scattering amplitudes calculated by
Lagrangian field theory are expressed as (13) it usually happens that the representation
must be modified by the addition of polynomial in the cosine of the scattering angle. A
polynomial Qn (cos θ) will only affect the nth partial wave and will therefore leave the function
al (t) unchanged. The existence of such a term will mean however that the function al (t)
is not equal to the physical partial wave at l = n. In other words the Regge function
3

 fp (ω, t) will contain Kronecher delta singularities at l = n if it is to represent the physical
partial waves correctly. If a theory has an elementary particle of spin σ, a Kronecher delta
singularity will occurr at l = σ in the channel of the quantum numbers of the elementary
particle. In quantum electrodynamics the photon remains an elementary particle but the
electron does Reggeize, the Kronecher delta singularity arising in the Born approximation
on account of one-electron exchange in the t-channel disappears as a consequence of the
radiative corrections. In quantum chromodynamics the gluon and the quarks Reggeize.
Especially important is the gluon Reggeization, because of the non-decreasing with energy
of the total cross sections are provided by gluon exchanges. At each order of perturbation
theory amplitudes with negative signatures do dominate, owing to cancellation of the leading
logarithmic terms in the amplitudes with positive signature [2], [3]. The Pomeron emerges as
compound of two reggeized gluons. The high energy scattering amplitude for the colourless
particle described by the Feynman diagrams containing only two intermediate gluons with
momenta k and q − k in the t channel has the Mellin transform
Z Y 2 2 ′
d ρr d ρr

Φ(ρ~1 , ρ~2 , q~′ )fω (ρ~1 , ρ~2 , ρ~′1 , ρ~′2 )Φ(ρ~′1 , ρ~′2 , q~′ ).
(20)
(2π)4

The impact factors Φ describe the inner structure of the colliding particles, the quantity
fω (ρ~1 , ρ~2 , ρ~′1 , ρ~′2 ) can be considered as a four-point gluon Green function in a two-dimensional
impact parameter space. It depends on ρik = ρi − ρk . Due to the colourless property of the
colliding particles the fω (ρ~1 , ρ~2 , ρ~′1 , ρ~′2 ) can be recast into Moebius invariant form depending
only on the two anharmonic ratios of the vectors ρ~1 , ρ~2 ,ρ~′1 ,ρ~′2 chosen as follows
α=

ρ11′ ρ22′

ρ11′ ρ22′
ρ12 ρ1′ 2′

(21)

here ρk = xk + iyk ρk ∗ = xk − iyk for all two dimensional vectors ρ~k = (xk , yk ). A worldsheet structure is emerging even in the perturbative description of the pomeron. In this
paper we are going to explore how in closed bosonic string theory a pomeron description is
emerging from pure world-sheet calculations. In section two we review the vertex operator
of the pomeron in string theory in flat space and we provide the coupling of the pomeron
to the colliding asymptotic string states. In section three we consider the Regge limit of the
scattering amplitude of two dilatons going to two dilatons in an ADS5 background and we
confirm the deviation from the linearity of the Regge trajectories as found in ([4]). Section
four is for conclusions and discussions.

2

Regge behaviour in string theory in flat space

Consider a bosonic string moving in a Minkowskian flat background of 26 dimensions. According to the usual notations in string theory the metric tensor is ημν = diag(−1, 1, 1......),
and we will be using such a metric tensor in the following. The Moebius fixed VirasoroShapiro amplitude for the 2 −→ 2 closed string tachyons is given by

Regge behaviour in warped space

In this section we revisited the arguments of ([4]) to investigate about the Regge limit for
the analogous of (22) in the warped space background ADS5 . The metric is
ds2 =

V1 = eip1 X ψ1 (Y ) V2 = eip2 X ψ2 (Y ),
X(z, z̄) and Y (z, z̄) are the coordinates of the string and so the world-sheet fields. Following
[7], [8] we assume that at the lowest order in the world-sheet perturbation theory, the worldsheet supersymmetry as well the Ramond-Ramond fluxes do not make any contribution. So
in the following the dynamics will be given by the non-linear σ-model

(56)

and correct our Regge trajectory in √1λ by simply renormalizing at one loop the result (56).
This procedure just consists into compute the one loop anomalous dimension of the tensor
term in (56) inside the σ model (52). The one-loop OPE is given by
|z|−4+Dop : exp[ikX(0, 0)][1 − |z|2 p1μ p1ν ∂X μ ∂X ν + ......]ψ1 (Y (0, 0))ψ2 (Y (0, 0)) :

(57)

the −4 in the Wilson coefficient exponent is because the vertex operators V1 and V2 are
on-shell. Dop is the anomalous dimension operator for (56). To determine such an operator
acting on a given vertex operator Ω(z, z̄) we use the standard perturbative renormalization
theory techniques. The change Ω̇ results by applying an external Liouville field σ in the
usual conformal rescaling of the world-sheet metric ηαβ −→ γαβ = e2σ ηαβ . In the limit of
small curvature of the ADS5 space or, wich is the same, in the limit of strong coupling λ,
related each others by [9]

Conclusions and discussions

In this paper we performed an analysis of the pomeron in closed string theory. The couplings
of the pomeron vertex operator to some of the closed string states have been explicitly computed. The utility of such quantities consists into providing the asymptotic Regge behaviour
of the scattering amplitude of a two by two process. Giving the coupling (29), the two by two
scattering amplitude (22) is reduced to the computation of the three point Green function
C12 < 0|VP (0)V3 (1)V4 (∞)|0 > .

(71)

Regge behaviour in a warped space like ADS5 is still not fully understood and the result (70)
for our scattering amplitude is done in some semiclassical approximation. The qualitative
meaning is not so different from the one of [4] neverthless the methods of derivation are not
the same. In this paper the calculation of the anomalous dimension of the massless vertex
operator as done by [10] has been used assuming that the two derivative operator gives
the dominant contribution in the Regge operator product expansion (59). This is the same
assumption as in [4], neverthless we do not make use of the basis of the many derivatives
operators
 ̄ + ∂X + ) 2j eikX φ+j .

since for j different than zero and two a complicated mixing is expected in the one loop
world-sheet renormalization with a very complicated anomalous dimension operator. Of
12

that the anomalous dimension for the operator V (j) was

where ∆j is the covariant Laplacian for the j-tensor φ+j , we have found δ2 6= 0 due to the
contribution in (61) from the Reimann tensor. This is a small shift in the Regge intercept
which can be neglected for an ADS5 space with small curvature. Probably something more
can be said by studying the problem in the global coordinates [8] where the ADS5 sigma
model (52) appears as an O(5, 1) non linear sigma model.
